Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Computational Physics in Atomic and Laser Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantum electrodynamics is a cornerstone of our current understanding of nature, as it describes the best understood of the four fundamental forces, the electromagnetic force, including relativistic and quantum effects which modify this force at very short distances. Almost all of the most accurately known fundamental constants are determined using the theory, and theoretical calculations in this field require some of the most advanced computational methods devised so far in theoretical physics. It is planned to illuminate the nature of various higher-order correction terms that currently influence one of the most pressing problems in theoretical physics, namely, the resolution of the muonic hydrogen conundrum, where theory and experiment are not in agreement. Various related interactions, including the loss of energy due to non-contact friction, have not been sufficiently understood in the microscopic world and yet are important, e.g., for the design of nanostructured devices (nanotechnology).

The broader impact of the work will include potential applications in the nanoworld, and the determination of fundamental constants, as well as investigations regarding their conceivable variation with time. Another impact is on numerical algorithms for so-called special functions describing physical and technical processes, and for the diagonalization of matrices where industrial applications can also be envisaged. The education of a graduate student forms an integral part of the proposed research endeavour.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Within a total of 36 refereed publications in international scientific journals, a number of questions of prime public interest could be addressed in the research funded by NSF. These include the question of how antiparticles behave in gravitational fields. Namely, in 1928, the Swiss-French physicist Paul A. M. Dirac had devised an equation which today bears his name and which is able to describe particles and antiparticles (with an intrinsic angular momentum, "spin", of one half) simultaneously, i.e., the equation can be separated into components which describe electrons, and those which describe positrons (the antiparticles). It was possible to show, using a coupling of the Dirac particle to the curved space-time background, that the gravitational terms in the separated Hamiltonian posses a specific symmetry which dictates that electrons and positrons, at least in central, static gravitational fields, behave exactly the same, i.e., they are both attracted to the gravitational field, and that includes all the so-called relativistic quantum corrections of motion. The mass term in the Dirac equation, for both electrons and positrons, which is a priori an inertial mass term, can thus be identified with the gravitational mass, for both particles as well as antiparticles. The combination of techniques from atomic physics (bound-state quantum electrodynamics, QED) as well as general relativity was decisive in obtaining this result. Other results include a theoretically predicted increase, by orders of magnitude, of the friction experienced  by an atom as it moves through interstellar space and absorbs blue-shifted cosmic background radiation from the front, and emits it in all directions, leading to an effective energy loss.  These are complemented by the realization that the so-called imaginary part of the atomic polarizability (the "absorptive frequency-dependent response of the atom to incoming light) in the infrared, can be described by a simple analytic formula which follows from a quantum electrodynamic treatment of the problem (a "one-loop calculation"). All of these results were published in Physical Review Letters. Finally, it was possible to clarify the theory behind the coherent emission of three photons by electrons kicked by an incoming energetic light quantum, i.e., a photon. This so-called triple Compton scattering process has interesting angular characteristics which could be compared to an experiment which hitherto lacked a theoretical description. A total of 8 publications were prepared by the PI alone, as a single author, and many resulted as collaborations with international colleagues, and visiting scholars at the home institution, which is Missouri University of Science and Technology in Rolla, Missouri, USA. The research combines theoretical techniques from laser physics, quantum electrodynamics, general relativity, and computational physics.
